title.value: Efficient Epistemic Uncertainty Estimation in Regression Ensemble Models Using Pairwise-Distance Estimators
title.justification: This is the exact title given at the beginning and repeated several times in the document.
title.quote: Efficient Epistemic Uncertainty Estimation in Regression Ensemble Models Using Pairwise-Distance Estimators

extractions.description: This paper introduces Pairwise-Distance Estimators (PaiDEs) as a method for estimating epistemic uncertainty in regression ensemble models with probabilistic outputs. It claims considerable improvements in computational efficiency over traditional Monte Carlo methods, demonstrating the advantages of PaiDEs through various regression tasks across different datasets.

type.justification: The paper involves conducting experiments and tests on different regression tasks and comparing methods for uncertainty estimation, thus making it an empirical study.
type.quote: To validate our approach, we conducted a varied series of regression experiments on commonly used benchmarks: 1D sinusoidal data, Pendulum, Hopper, Ant and Humanoid.

name.justification: The primary goal of the paper is to estimate epistemic uncertainty efficiently in regression ensemble models.
name.quote: This work introduces an efficient novel approach for epistemic uncertainty estimation for ensemble models for regression tasks using pairwise-distance estimators (PaiDEs).

name.justification: Active Learning is discussed as a framework used to demonstrate the advantages of PaiDEs.
name.quote: We leverage this capability to enhance the performance of Bayesian Active Learning by Disagreement (BALD).

name.justification: The context of the entire study is based on regression tasks, making it a significant subfield.
name.quote: In this paper, we propose Pairwise-Distance Estimators (PaiDEs) as a non-sample based method for estimating epistemic uncertainty in deep ensembles with probabilistic outputs for regression tasks.

name.justification: Normalizing Flows (NFs) were used as the primary ensemble technique to demonstrate the PaiDEs method.
name.quote: The primary ensemble utilized in this study is a collection of Normalizing Flows (NFs), known for their effectiveness in capturing heteroscedastic and complex multi-modal aleatoric uncertainty.

name.justification: The primary ensemble technique used in this study involved Normalizing Flows, which is referred to as Nflows Base.
name.quote: The primary ensemble utilized in this study is a collection of Normalizing Flows (NFs), known for their effectiveness in capturing heteroscedastic and complex multi-modal aleatoric uncertainty.

is_contributed.justification: The paper leverages the existing normalizing flows technique rather than contributing a new model.
is_contributed.quote: ensemble technique named Nflows Base, which has previously shown robust performance in estimating both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty on simulated robotic datasets

is_executed.justification: The model was executed in the empirical experiments conducted in the study.
is_executed.quote: To validate our approach, we conducted a varied series of regression experiments on commonly used benchmarks: 1D sinusoidal data, Pendulum, Hopper, Ant and Humanoid.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares its PaiDEs method to other uncertainty estimation methods, implying the models themselves were also compared.
is_compared.quote: We compare our approach to existing active learning methods and find that our approach outperforms on high-dimensional regression tasks.
